title: 111_hr4105
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Healthy Air for Federal Workers Act". Congress finds that in 2006, the Surgeon General concluded that there is no safe level of exposure to secondhand smoke, which causes disease and premature death in children and adults. Exposure to secondhand smoke has immediate adverse effects on the cardiovascular system, leading to coronary heart disease and lung cancer. The only way to prevent exposure is to eliminate it, as other approaches like air ventilation systems do not work. According to the American Lung Association, 23 States are affected by secondhand smoke. According to the American Lung Association, 23 States have passed comprehensive smoke-free laws protecting workers. The smoking of tobacco products is prohibited within 25 feet of any entrances, exits, windows, or ventilation intakes of Federal buildings. An exception is made for smoking conducted solely for research purposes by an agency. Enforcement measures are outlined. The Administrator of General Services, along with agency heads, enforces compliance with the Act in Executive Branch buildings. The House Office Building Commission, Senate Committee on Rules and Administration, and Architect of the Capitol enforce the prohibition in Legislative Branch buildings. The Director of the Administrative Office of the United States Courts will enforce the prohibition in Federal buildings used by the Federal courts and the judicial branch. Implementation of this Act will begin within 3 months of enactment. The Administrator of General Services, in collaboration with agency heads, will oversee activities in Federal buildings described in the Act. The Director of the Administrative Office of the United States Courts will inform employees and visitors about the smoke-free policy in Federal buildings, educate them on the dangers of secondhand smoke, and undertake necessary related activities. SEC. 5. NO LIMITATION OR PREEMPTION OF MORE PROTECTIVE POLICIES.

(a) Nothing in this Act limits the ability of certain authorities to establish stricter workplace smoking policies.
(b) This Act does not override any other laws that offer greater protection from secondhand smoke.

SEC. 6. REPORT. Within 6 months of the Act's enactment, reports on its implementation by the Administrator of General Services and the Director of the Administrative Office of the United States Courts will be submitted to Congress. Definitions are provided in Section 7. The Act defines "Federal building" as any building owned or leased by the Federal Government for use by the executive or legislative branch, Federal courts, or the judicial branch. The term "agency" refers to Executive agencies as defined in title 5, United States Code. The term "smoking" in government regulations includes the combustion of tobacco products like cigarettes, cigars, and pipes.
